elements.title: Discussion on Strategic Acquisitions, Divestitures and Restructuring

data.value: The company has made strategic acquisitions of businesses, technologies, and other assets, most recently through a significant acquisition.
The company may engage in acquisitions, divestitures, or other strategic transactions in the future, which could disrupt business operations and impact financial conditions.
Future transactions may be funded through cash, equity issuance (potential dilution), or debt, with associated risks if efficiencies are not achieved.
Risks include difficulties integrating acquired operations, challenges in divesting assets without harming the core business, management distraction, and potential adverse reactions from investors.

The company is also undertaking restructuring plans to cut costs and realign its operating structure, although these may incur substantial costs and risks including reputational and litigation issues.
Delays in customer purchases and challenges in executing strategic transactions may negatively affect revenue, financial condition, and overall results.

Shares held beneficially in street name may be voted virtually at the Annual Meeting if a legal proxy is obtained from the broker, bank, trustee or nominee. A 16‐digit control number on the proxy card or voting instructions is required.

Stockholders of record can vote by proxy, Internet, telephone, or mail. Beneficial owners must submit voting instructions through their broker, bank, trustee or nominee or attend virtually with an authorized proxy form.

Shareholders may change or revoke their proxy vote by submitting a written notice of revocation, a subsequent proxy card, or by casting a timely Internet or telephone vote, as long as it is received prior to the vote at the Annual Meeting.

If no specific voting selections are made, votes will be cast 'FOR' the nominees in Proposal 1, 'FOR' Proposals 2, 3 and 5, and a '1 YEAR' vote in Proposal 4 for stockholders of record, while beneficial owners without voting instructions result in non-votes on Proposals 1-4 and delegated discretion on Proposal 5 by their broker.
The Company will bear all expenses related to soliciting proxies for the Annual Meeting and may reimburse brokers, custodians, nominees, and fiduciaries for their reasonable expenses.

Seven out of nine of our directors, including our Chair, are independent in accordance with the rules and regulations of the SEC and the listing standards of Nasdaq.

The Board consists of a diverse group of professionals who bring significant experience, leadership and distinct qualities and skill sets to Infinera. Three out of nine of our directors are female (33%), one of whom was appointed as chair of our Compensation Committee during 2022 upon relinquishing her position as chair of our Nominating and Governance Committee. One of our directors is an "underrepresented minority," as such term is defined under Nasdaq Rule 5605(f) (the "Nasdaq Board Diversity Rule"). While we believe the current composition of the Board provides a diverse range of perspectives and experience to engage each other and management to effectively represent our stockholders, we will continue to consider gender, cultural and ethnic diversity when evaluating potential changes to our Board membership.
We have separated the positions of Chair and Chief Executive Officer ("CEO").
The Board and its committees assess their performance through an annual self-evaluation.
The average tenure of our current Board members is approximately five years. We have refreshed our Board by appointing five new directors since the beginning of fiscal 2020.
We have three standing committees of the Board — Audit, Compensation, and Nominating and Governance. All committees are composed entirely of independent directors.
Each non-employee director is required to own shares of Infinera common stock having a value of at least four times the annual cash retainer for service as a director.

Members of our senior management team are responsible for implementation of our day-to-day risk management processes, while the Board, as a whole and through its committees, has oversight of risk management.

We pay base salaries to attract, retain and motivate our executive officers for their day-to-day contributions.

We provide annual incentive cash compensation to link payments to the achievement of our annual financial and/or operational objectives. We had cancelled this program in response to impacts from the COVID-19 pandemic for the second half of fiscal 2020 and all of fiscal 2021, but reinstated an annual incentive cash compensation program for our CEO and CFO in fiscal 2022. For our other NEOs, the annual incentive compensation program was reinstated in fiscal 2022 with 50% of the target value in retention RSUs and 50% of the target value in cash. Our SVP, Worldwide Sales participated in this annual incentive compensation program (including the 50%/50% ratio between cash and retention equity) as to 25% of his target value and also participated in a separate incentive compensation program as to 75% of his target value that was tied to achievement of new financial targets for bookings and gross profit, measured on a non-GAAP basis.

We provide long-term incentive compensation delivered in the form of time-based and performance-based equity awards to more closely align the interests of our executive officers with those of our stockholders and provide significant motivational and retention value to our executive officers.

elements.title: Executive Clawback and Stock Ownership Policies

data.value: The document outlines the Executive Clawback Policy applicable to Section 16 Officers and directors, including each NEO. Under this policy, the Compensation Committee has the authority to seek repayment of cash incentive payments, cancellation of unvested/unexercised/unreleased equity awards, and recovery of compensation earned on awards if financial results were impacted by fraud, embezzlement, gross negligence, or deliberate disregard of rules leading to significant monetary loss. The policy also covers recovery following a financial restatement per Section 304 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.

The policy requires Section 16 Officers and directors to hold a minimum number of shares of Infinera common stock within three years from the effective date or appointment date. Shares include those owned directly by the officer/director or their immediate family and those held in trust. Stock value is determined by the greater of the last trading closing price or the actual purchase price. Specific ownership requirements are highlighted in a table.

The table specifies that the CEO must hold 4x annual base salary, the CFO 2x annual base salary, and other Section 16 Officers and employee directors 1x annual base salary. This tiered requirement links executive interests to those of stockholders.

The document also details that, under the Insider Trading Policy, employees, including NEOs and Board members, are prohibited from hedging risks associated with their stock ownership and from pledging Infinera securities as collateral.

elements.title: Tax and Accounting Treatment of Compensation & Compensation Committee Report

data.value: Section 162(m) limits tax deductibility of compensation over $1 million for CEO, CFO, and other top executives unless performance-based criteria are met. The performance-based exception was eliminated in 2017 and extended to additional employees.

Deductibility for compensation exceeding $1 million may only be allowed if qualifying for transition relief applicable to arrangements in place on November 2, 2017. There is no guarantee that compensation will qualify.
Historically, no formal policy on tax deductibility was adopted; however, the Compensation Committee aims to strongly link executive pay to performance.
Equity compensation is accounted for under ASC 718, requiring expense recognition over the service period; cash compensation is expensed when the obligation is incurred.

The Compensation Committee, including Sharon E. Holt (Chair), Gregory P. Dougherty, and Paul J. Milbury, recommended inclusion of this analysis in the Proxy Statement and Annual Report on Form 10-K for fiscal year ended December 31, 2022.

elements.title: EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION TABLES - Fiscal 2022 Summary Compensation Table

data.value: The table provides executive compensation data for key executives from fiscal years 2020 to 2022. It includes details such as Salary, Bonus, Stock Awards, Non-Equity Incentive Plan Compensation, Other Compensation, and Total Compensation for individuals including CEO David W. Heard, Chief Executive Officer (2021 and 2020), CFO Nancy L. Erba, Chief Financial Officer (2021 and 2020), Chief Legal Officer and Corporate Secretary David L. Teichmann (across years), and Senior Vice President, Worldwide Sales Nicholas R. Walden (across years).

CEO David W. Heard achieved the highest total compensation in 2022 at $6,260,700, driven mainly by stock awards of $4,855,638. Stock awards are consistently the largest component of the executives' compensation packages, and bonuses were relatively rare. Overall, the data shows general increases in compensation over the three-year period.

Salary data is based on payroll records by fiscal year. For fiscal 2020, temporary base salary reductions were implemented due to COVID-19 impacts from May 23, 2020 to December 4, 2020. Stock awards values are determined in accordance with ASC 718, with grant date fair values provided. Non-equity incentive plan compensation reflects performance for the year but is paid in the subsequent March. Additional details regarding bonus payouts and other compensation items are provided in accompanying narratives and footnotes.

Restricted Stock Units Activity Summary

This table tracks Restricted Stock Units (RSUs) activity over three years (2019–2022). It details annual grants, releases, and cancellations. Outstanding units increased from 11,600 in December 2019 to 12,588 in December 2022. Weighted-average grant date fair values rose from $6.20 to $8.13, with aggregate intrinsic values peaking at $136,781 in December 2020 before a decline by year‐end 2022.

Our sales cycle may take several quarters from initial contact to signing a purchase agreement.
North America, LATAM, EMEA, APAC.

San Jose, Allentown, Annapolis, Bangalore, Kanata, Stockholm, Munich, Lisbon, Shanghai.

elements.title: Launch of Coherent Optical Pluggables Suite

data.value: Designed to address the rapidly growing market for point-to-point and point-to-multipoint solutions, enabling cost-efficient network architecture.
High-speed transport rates including 800 Gb/s, 400 Gb/s, and 100 Gb/s optical semiconductor technology.
Managed by software solutions enabling simplified network management and automated operations, including Instant Bandwidth.
30% or more year-over-year growth in bandwidth demand.
Infinera Corporation
December 2000
6373 San Ignacio Avenue, San Jose, CA 95119
Infinera, FlexCoherent, Infinera logo.
Growth in cloud services, over-the-top services, mobile broadband, edge computing, virtual/augmented reality devices, and IoT.
We have focused our efforts and capital on developing high-performance, vertically integrated transport technologies and solutions.
Deep vertical integration of high-end optical technology, including optical semiconductors.
Achievements include the first large-scale PIC, first coherent PIC, and first commercial super-channels.
In-house developed technology and unique monolithic InP semiconductor technology.
Hardware product portfolio includes compact modular platforms, packet-optical platforms, optical line systems, and optical subsystems.
Infinera Transcend Software Suite includes automation and network management software.
End-to-end transport infrastructure, including metro, long-haul, subsea, and DCI.
Designed to meet the needs of ICPs, communication service providers, and data center operators.
Compact modular platforms optimized for transport network applications.
Delivers up to 2.4 Tb/s of line-side capacity for various networks.
Infinera Groove (GX) Series
Supports muxponder functionality and multi-haul optical line systems.
Configurable system for various optical networking applications.
Infinera 7300 Series
SDN-ready coherent optical transport system; supports regional, long-haul, and ultra-long-haul optical networking.
Infinera FlexILS Open Optical Line System
Connects various terminal equipment over long-distance fiber optic cable; supports ROADM functionality.
Infinera 7090 Series
MPLS-TP and Carrier Ethernet-based options for diverse applications.
Infinera XTM Series
Enables high-performance metro connectivity solutions; optimized for 5G and metro transport.
Infinera 7100 Series
Flexible mix of transponders and switching options; optimized for metro transport.

elements.title: Infinera Product Launches: mTera Series and XTC Series

data.value: mTera Series
Flexible and efficient network transport solution supporting scalable grooming and innovative protocol-agnostic switch fabric.
4 Tb/s shelf and 7 Tb/s shelf
SDN-ready, advanced ROADM capabilities.
XTC Series
Multi-terabit packet optical transport platforms integrating digital OTN switching and optical DWDM transmission.
Converged packet, OTN, and DWDM for metro core, regional, long-haul, and subsea applications.
ICE-X Coherent Pluggable Optics
Suite of coherent pluggable optics addressing point-to-point and point-to-multipoint transport applications.
800 Gb/s, 400 Gb/s and 100 Gb/s.
Communications service providers, ICPs, enterprises and third-party equipment manufacturers.
Transcend Software Suite with automation capabilities for network operators.
Significant investments in manufacturing processes, automation, equipment, facilities, and workforce training to improve production and packaging.
Manufacturing and packaging operations in California and Pennsylvania, including a fabrication facility for PICs and a module manufacturing facility.
Utilization of three contract manufacturers across countries such as Thailand, Malaysia, China, Mexico, and Hungary, with capability to shift production to U.S. factories if needed.
Institutionalized strategies for mitigating supply chain risks including rigorous in-house quality control testing.

data.value: Ernst & Young LLP
December 30, 2023

The Audit Committee has selected Ernst & Young LLP as our independent auditors. Their appointment is submitted for ratification by stockholders at the Annual Meeting as a matter of good corporate practice. Representatives may attend the meeting to respond to questions. The Audit Committee reserves the right to change auditors if necessary.
Fiscal 2022 fees were higher due to additional fees related to the issuance of convertible senior notes due August 1, 2028. No audit-related fees were incurred in fiscal 2022 or 2021.
Three non-employee directors: Paul J. Milbury (Chair), Christine Bucklin, Roop K. Lakkaraju; with Lakkaraju and Milbury identified as Audit Committee Financial Experts.
To assist the Board in oversight of accounting practices, internal controls, audit processes, financial reporting, and cybersecurity risk management.

Appointing and retaining the independent auditor, approving audit and non-audit services, reviewing financial statements, internal control over financial reporting, audit results, and related risk management issues.
Met fourteen times during fiscal 2022, including meetings with internal auditors, independent auditors, and management in both open and executive sessions.
Ernst & Young LLP, responsible for independent audit of consolidated financial statements and internal control reporting.
Reviewed annually; available on the company website under the Governance section of the Investors page.

Difference between stockholder of record and beneficial owner: Stockholders of Record have shares registered directly in their name, while Beneficial Owners hold shares through a broker, bank, trustee or other nominee.
Beneficial owners must instruct their broker, bank, trustee, or nominee on how to vote, and may need to obtain a legal proxy to vote virtually at the Annual Meeting.
Stockholders of record as of the close of business on the Record Date are entitled to vote, with one vote per share.
As of the Record Date, 224,825,462 shares of common stock were outstanding and entitled to vote at the Annual Meeting.

A majority of the shares entitled to vote – either present virtually or represented by a properly submitted proxy – is required to constitute a quorum. Abstentions and broker non-votes count towards the quorum.
A broker non-vote occurs when a broker does not vote on non-routine proposals due to lack of discretionary voting power. These votes count toward the quorum but not the vote totals.

Non-routine proposals (Proposals 1-4) require direct instructions and do not benefit from broker discretionary voting, while routine proposals (e.g., Proposal 5 on ratifying the accounting firm) may be voted by brokers without instructions.
Stockholders of record can vote virtually using the 16-digit control number provided on their proxy card or voting instructions.

elements.title: Product Development, Introduction, and Supply Chain Risks

data.value: Extensive quality assurance, reliability testing, and staffing of testing infrastructure are critical steps.
Validation of software and establishment of systems integration and systems test validation requirements.
Risks of failure, rework, or delay in product introduction that could reduce market acceptance and competitive positioning.
Includes risks from intellectual property disputes, licensing issues, failure of critical design elements, and constrained engineering resources.
Issues such as delays, shortages, discontinued components and increased costs; global supply chain disruptions adversely affecting production and revenue.
Efforts such as additional or long-term purchase commitments and higher inventory levels might negatively impact financial results if demand forecasts are inaccurate.

elements.title: Risk Factors - Competitive Environment and Market Pressures

data.value: The document details how increased competition, especially for large or high-profile opportunities, and economic downturns can lead to heightened pricing pressure and impact demand for products.
It mentions that if the company fails to compete effectively, it could experience a decline in product demand, order delays or cancellations, and may need to reduce prices.

Competitors identified include DWDM system suppliers such as ADVA Optical Networking, Ciena Corporation, Cisco Systems, Ribbon Communications Inc., Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd., Nokia, and ZTE, among others.
An example is given where in March 2021, Cisco completed its acquisition of optical communications supplier Acacia Communications.

Competition is noted to be based on price, commercial terms, product functionality and performance, customer relationships, component availability, power consumption, quality, service levels, and lead times among other factors.

elements.title: Риски, связанные с производительностью продукции и качеством компонентов

data.value: Обсуждаются проблемы с производительностью продукции, включая ошибки в аппаратном и программном обеспечении, а также возможные задержки в эксплуатации продуктов, что может негативно сказаться на операционных результатах и репутации компании.

Упоминаются сложности разработки и производства высокотехнологичных продуктов, в том числе потенциальные проблемы с интеграцией сложных аппаратных и программных решений, ошибки или баги, которые могут быть выявлены только после релиза.

Отмечены риски, связанные с поставкой комплектующих от сторонних производителей, которые могут не соответствовать спецификациям, что приводит к замене компонентов или необходимости проведения ПО-ремонтов.

Указываются последствия, такие как снижение заказов, задержки в признании выручки, увеличение расходов на исправление ошибок, возможные компенсационные выплаты, ухудшение качества сервиса и рост уровня возвратов продукции.
Подчеркивается риск возникновения сбоев в цепочке поставок, влияющих как на клиентов, так и на операционные процессы компании.

elements.title: Risks Due to COVID-19 Pandemic and Public Health Concerns

data.value: The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and future public health concerns could materially adversely affect business, manufacturing operations, and overall results of operations.

Experiences of temporary closures, reduced on-site personnel, travel restrictions, and modified participation in industry events have led to delays in operational processes and disruptions in global supply chains.
Dependency on sole or limited source suppliers for key components, such as semiconductors, has resulted in capacity issues, increased costs, longer lead times, and shortages.

The reliance on key personnel and challenges in attracting and retaining skilled employees, particularly given the remote/hybrid work setups and competitive labor market, pose risks to operational effectiveness.
Uncertainties regarding infection rates, emergence of new viruses, availability of vaccinations, and global macroeconomic developments contribute to the risk landscape.

elements.title: Dependence on Key Customers and Manufacturing Risks

data.value: A small number of key customers generate a large percentage of revenue with top ten customers accounting for 42%-48% of revenue, and loss or reduction in orders could harm revenue and operating results.
Sales made under standard purchase agreements can be canceled or reduced at short notice, impacting revenue before operating expenses can be adjusted.
Complex manufacturing processes for optical engines and related components expose the business to risks such as facility loss, yield variances, production suspensions, and delays in scaling capacity.
Failure to maintain competitive relationships with key customers and adverse global economic conditions may further harm the business.

elements.title: Risks from Increased Consolidation and Supplier/Contract Manufacturer Dependence

data.value: Increased consolidation among customers and suppliers in the communications networking industry adversely affects buying patterns, pricing, spending, and customer dependency.
Fewer customers generate a significant portion of revenue, leading to changes in buying patterns, reduced spending, and heightened pricing and competitive pressures.
Recent consolidations, including acquisitions like II-VI acquiring Finisar (2019) and Coherent (2022), may increase component prices, cause delays, or disrupt output.

Dependence on third-party contract manufacturers poses risks including reduced control over delivery schedules, quality assurance issues, yield uncertainties, capacity limitations, and potential disruptions in meeting product specifications.
Risks associated with geopolitical events, natural disasters, social factors, or international health emergencies could further impair manufacturing and delivery schedules.

elements.title: Risk Factors Related to Forecasting, Inventory and Supply Chain Challenges

data.value: Failure to accurately forecast manufacturing requirements or customer demand may lead to additional costs such as inventory write-downs and equipment write-offs.
Significant investments are made months in advance of revenue recognition due to long lead times for materials and components.
Extended lead times for components driven by industry-wide supply chain challenges complicate the forecasting process.
Overestimating demand may result in excess inventory and increased risk of obsolescence, while underestimating demand can disrupt production and shipment delays.
Large customers may negotiate favorable commercial terms, potentially resulting in lower selling prices, increased costs, and reduced gross margins.
Lengthy and unpredictable sales cycles, compounded by supply chain issues, may delay revenue recognition and affect overall profitability.
Inflation-related cost increases might not be fully passed on to customers, thereby impacting profitability if unfavorable commercial terms are agreed upon.

elements.title: Risk Factors: Economic Uncertainty, Supply Chain Disruptions & Financing Challenges

data.value: The COVID-19 pandemic has created significant uncertainty in global macroeconomic conditions, affecting capital and credit markets.
Supply chains are experiencing high levels of disruption, volatility, and uncertainty, which may negatively impact product delivery and manufacturing schedules.
Tightening credit markets and liquidity issues could lead customers to delay, cancel purchases, or default on payment obligations.
Currency fluctuations may adversely affect the purchasing ability or desire of international customers.

Reliance on external financing such as convertible senior notes, credit agreements, and open market sales highlights risks; future capital may be unavailable or come with unfavorable terms, impacting growth and refinancing.
Existing and future financing agreements include restrictive covenants that may limit operational flexibility and strategic initiatives.

elements.title: Risk Factors – International Operations and Supply Chain Disruptions

data.value: The company is attempting to increase international market demand for its products amid strong competition from companies with greater name recognition and a stronger sales and marketing presence.

Reliance on development centers in diverse international locations (Canada, China, Finland, Germany, India, Portugal, Sweden) may not result in meaningful cost reductions or greater resource efficiency.
New or continuing disruptions in the global supply chain could impair the ability to deliver products and provide installation/maintenance services in a timely and efficient manner.

Operations in Russia have been affected by sanctions and trade controls related to Russia's military actions in Ukraine, disrupting existing contracts despite a low revenue percentage from the region.

Risks include difficulties in collecting accounts receivable, managing and staffing international offices, increased travel and legal compliance costs, and exposure to political, social, and economic instability.
Fluctuations in currency exchange rates, especially an increase in the value of the U.S. dollar relative to other currencies, could negatively affect financial results and cash flows.

The concentration of storage and distribution facilities in one location in southeastern Asia exposes operations to local/regional risks such as natural disasters, accidents, system failures, and other unforeseen events.

elements.title: Risk Factors – International Operations and Regulatory Compliance

data.value: Risks related to logistics, fulfillment issues, and increased costs due to inventory management challenges.
Exposure to complex international and U.S. laws including anti-corruption (FCPA, UK Bribery Act), antitrust, anti-money laundering, trade controls, national security, and data privacy laws.
Impact of currency exchange rate fluctuations on financial results, partially mitigated through foreign currency exchange forward contracts.
Potential increase or fluctuation in the effective tax rate due to various factors including changes in deferred tax asset valuations and legislative changes such as the Inflation Reduction Act.
The ability to manage these risks is critical to international operations, affecting business, financial condition, and operating results.

elements.title: Tax Law and Convertible Notes Risk Disclosures

data.value: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and the European Union are considering and adopting changes to tax laws, including a proposal for a 15% global minimum tax, which could increase tax obligations and affect operations.

The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017 eliminated the immediate deduction for R&D expenditures, requiring these expenses to be amortized over five (U.S.) and fifteen (foreign) tax years, potentially increasing the effective tax rate and reducing operating cash flows.

Issuance and conversion of convertible senior notes (2024, 2027, 2028 Notes) may result in dilution of existing stockholders and adversely affect the market price of common stock, especially if convertible notes are converted or additional shares are issued.

Provisions related to fundamental changes in the convertible notes may allow note holders to require repurchase or adjust conversion rates, which could delay or prevent a beneficial takeover and be dilutive to current shareholders.
The use of capped call transactions to mitigate dilution risk introduces counterparty risk, as any default by the financial institution counterparties can impact the market price of the common stock.
Legal and Regulatory Risk Factors
Exposure under Capped Calls tied to market price increases, volatility, and counterparty defaults may lead to adverse tax consequences and dilution.
Reliance on protecting proprietary technology via trade secrets, patents, copyrights, trademarks and confidentiality measures, with risks of misappropriation and infringement.
Potential litigation to enforce or defend intellectual property rights, which could incur significant costs and divert management resources.
Competitors with extensive patent portfolios and greater resources for IP enforcement may intensify infringement claims.

Указание на возможность предъявления претензий со стороны конкурентов и третьих лиц относительно нарушения прав, что может привести к длительным судебным процессам и финансовым издержкам.

Риски, связанные с интерпретацией лицензионных условий открытого программного обеспечения, которые могут потребовать получения дополнительных лицензий, переработки продуктов или прекращения их продажи.

Описаны риски, связанные с кибератаками, утечками данных и другими инцидентами безопасности, которые могут нарушить работу сетей, привести к несанкционированному доступу к конфиденциальной информации и нанести ущерб репутации.

elements.title: Regulatory, Trade, Environmental and ESG Risks

data.value: The text outlines negative consequences including reputational harm, government investigations, and penalties due to compliance failures in trade, export, and environmental regulations.

elements.title: Риски, связанные с соблюдением законов по защите данных и кибербезопасности

data.value: Документ описывает влияние глобальных законов и нормативных требований в области конфиденциальности данных, защиты данных и кибербезопасности, таких как GDPR, PIPL, CCPA и CPRA, которые могут негативно сказаться на бизнесе через рост затрат на соблюдение требований, риск судебных разбирательств и убытков, а также осложнить работу с государственными контрактами через изменяющиеся требования к сертификации.

elements.title: Risks Related to Government Contracting Compliance and Legal Exposures

data.value: The document outlines the risks associated with government contracting, including compliance with laws, regulations, and contractual provisions. It highlights potential financial, operational, and reputational harm due to noncompliance, such as costly audits, internal investigations, security clearance issues, and exposure to legal penalties under various anti-bribery, anti-corruption, and anti-money laundering laws. It also discusses the risks of being unable to secure or maintain necessary security clearances, which could impact contract awards and renewals.
Partners or intermediaries may violate policies, potentially breaching FCPA, anti-bribery, anti-corruption, and anti-money laundering laws, leading to sanctions, legal actions, and investigations.

Violations could result in whistleblower complaints, fines, damages, adverse media coverage, loss of export privileges, and significant defense and professional fees, diverting management’s attention.
The trading price of common stock is highly volatile due to factors such as operating results, technological innovations, strategic alliances, mergers and acquisitions, and economic conditions.
Future sales of common stock, including at-the-market offerings, may dilute existing stockholders and depress the stock price.

Global trade tariffs, supply chain disruptions, fluctuations in currency exchange rates, interest rates, inflation, and geopolitical or health factors (e.g., pandemics) can adversely affect operations.

elements.title: Risk Factors: Dilution, Anti-Takeover Provisions and Jurisdictional Limitations

data.value: Issuance of a large number of common stock shares or convertible securities may dilute existing stockholders, potentially causing the stock price to fall.

The company's charter documents and Delaware law include anti-takeover measures, such as the issuance of 'blank check' convertible preferred stock, a classified board of directors, restrictions on removing directors, and limitations on special meeting calls and stockholder actions.

Exclusive forum provisions designate the Delaware Court of Chancery and federal district courts for dispute resolution, limiting stockholder ability to choose alternative forums, with some exceptions under federal law and concurrent jurisdiction under the Securities Act.
Collectively, these provisions pose risks regarding corporate control, potential dilution, and complexities in litigation that may adversely affect stockholder value.

elements.title: Risk Factors: Exclusive Forum Provisions and Operational Disruptions

data.value: The document discusses the potential need to litigate outside the designated exclusive forum, which could lead to significant additional costs and uncertainty if enforced differently across jurisdictions.
There is a risk that if courts do not enforce the exclusive forum provisions, the company may incur further costs and face challenges in dispute resolution.
The text highlights risks from natural disasters like earthquakes, fires, and floods, particularly impacting the company’s Northern California facilities and overall operations.

There is also mention of potential disruptions to the supply chain if critical facilities or infrastructure are compromised, which could adversely affect the company’s financial condition and results.

elements.title: Supply Chain Disruption and Third-Party Partner Risks

data.value: Reliance on various third-party service partners for installation, maintenance, logistics, and support functions creates potential vulnerabilities.
Qualifying a new contract manufacturer and commencing volume production is expensive and time-consuming, risking revenue loss and customer relationship damage.
Failure to effectively manage third-party relationships may result in delays in revenue recognition, liability issues, and overall adverse financial impact.
Rapid technological change and evolving industry standards require continuous investment, further stressing the supply chain and partner management.

Diversity, Equity and Inclusion (DEI)

values — values brought to life by our talented, diverse and dedicated global workforce. In 2022, we continued to invest in fostering a more inclusive work environment. In the U.S., we have commenced partnerships with non-profit institutions and historically black colleges and universities to increase our pipeline of diverse talent. We have also continued to provide access to DEI training for our global employee base. In our larger sites globally, we also provided training on inclusive hiring. We continued to expand Women at Infinera ("WIN") employee resource group activities and participation, including the introduction of our mentoring program, the formation of subcommittees and a speakers program addressing topics including development, recruitment and retention of women. In various locations, employees have also partnered with local nonprofit institutions and schools to encourage female students to pursue STEM careers.
Commitment to our Employees

We are dedicated to providing an inclusive and informative learning experience for each of our employees. In 2022, we rolled out a global online learning program to encourage employee personal and professional development. In addition, all of our full-time employees, and regular part-time employees working at least 24 hours per week, are eligible for general Infinera benefits.
Employee Health and Safety

We are proud of our strong safety culture and comprehensive health and safety management system, which is standardized around the globe. In 2022, we extended our health and safety programs to all sites to better track, manage and improve on health and safety metrics. We also implemented an incident and near miss reporting and tracking tool, which is available to all employees.
Carbon Emissions

It takes industry-wide effort to move the needle in mitigating climate change, and we are committed to doing our part to reduce emissions in our operations and from within our value chain. We currently have seven global sites that use 100% carbon free energy. In 2022, we submitted our carbon report through CDP (formerly the Carbon Disclosure Project) to share our emissions and progress toward our stated goals. Infinera received a score of "B-, Managed" which is an improvement over our first submission score in 2021 of "C, Awareness". In 2020, we committed to align with the Paris Agreement on climate change and reduce our greenhouse gas emissions. Though we have more work to do to meet our goal of a 50% reduction of greenhouse gases by 2030, through our CDP disclosures we intend to demonstrate transparency and accountability regarding our progress toward this important ESG goal.
